Message.Title: WSJ sings praise for the GOP Surrender Monkeys
Message.Msg: The conservative editorial page of the Wall Street Journal on Wednesday took aim at the Republican Party over the budget and debt limit. Although the Journal's editorial writers said that "both sides are looking like losers" in the dual crises consuming Washington, their most pointed shots targeted the GOP. "This is the quality of thinking—or lack thereof—that has afflicted many GOP conservatives from the beginning of this budget showdown," the editorial read. "They picked a goal they couldn't achieve in trying to defund ObamaCare from one House of Congress, and then they picked a means they couldn't sustain politically by pursuing a long government shutdown and threatening to blow through the debt limit." The Journal said that if the Senate passes its compromise to avert default and reopen the government, House Speaker John Boehner (R-OH) will likely have no choice "other than to bring it to the floor and let it pass with votes from either party." "At least that's better than getting the blame for whatever happens if Treasury stops sending out Social Security checks in order to prioritize debt repayments. The politics of that are little better than defaulting on debt. Republicans can best help their cause now by getting this over with and moving on to fight more intelligently another day." The WSJ's editorial page has been highly critical of the conservatives who led the foolishly impractical effort to defund the Affordable Care Act, urging them a month ago to give up their goal, and then taking aim at Senators Ted Cruz (R-TX) and Mike Lee (R-UT).

Message.Title: GRO China Stock on NYSE Owns 1/2 of $1 Billion Revenue Agriculture Company
Message.Msg: Agria (GRO) is the most insanely undervalued China stock at its current price of $1.55. GRO's China seeds business is one of the fastest growing Chinese businesses out of all publicly traded China stocks, with fiscal 2013 revenues up 98% to $17 million, yet it's currently receiving no value at all! This is because GRO's 80.81% owned Agria Asia subsidiary owns 50.22% of PGG Wrightson (PGW.NZ), New Zealand's largest publicly traded agricultural services company with over NZ$1 billion in revenues. PGW.NZ is trading in New Zealand at a six month high of NZ$0.39. Agria Asia's 379.1 million PGW.NZ shares are currently worth NZ$147.85 million and GRO's 80.81% stake is worth NZ$119.48 million (USD$101.56 million). New Hope, China's largest agribusiness company with USD$8.8 billion in annual revenue owns a minority 11.95% stake in GRO's Agria Asia, while Ngai Tahu owns the remaining 7.24%. GRO has only 55.38 million shares outstanding and a market cap at $1.55 of USD$85.84 million. Just GRO's 80.81% interest in Agria Asia, which owns 50.22% of PGW.NZ, is worth $101.56 million or $1.83 per share. With GRO's wholly owned China seeds business growing fiscal 2013 revenues by 98% to $17 million, a modest multiple of 2-3X sales will value it at $34-$51 million, which would add $0.61-$0.92 to GRO's share price and value GRO at $2.44-$2.75 per share! 3 of PGW.NZ's 7 Board members are from GRO's management, with a 4th Board member from the management of Ngai Tahu (one of Agria Asia's minority shareholders). This most likely gives GRO total control of PGW.NZ's Board of Directors. With PGW.NZ's Chairman retiring and their annual meeting on Tuesday, GRO could potentially capture the Chairmanship of PGW.NZ next week! Google this: "Seeds deal could grow enormous" and read this recent New Zealand Herald article about how huge GRO is about to become. Disclaimer: We own 550,000 shares of GRO and intend to sell them, and can do so at any time.

Message.Msg: Junior and Magoo like to end their posts often with " ,no " . Don't you find it odd that all three of you do that?? LOL What an idiot!! LOL
CSCO is a major sell, imo, they have a product line that is being commoditized and stolen by the Chinese, this is dead money at best the market is going into melt up and CSCO is going nowhere

Plenty of reasons to hold: * Leader in the networking infrastructure segment * Nearly a 3% dividend * Awesome cash flow * Awesome cash balance * Super-low PE (trailing and forward) * SDN threat overblown (besides, Cisco is working just as hard as anyone on evolving SDN) The "reasons" for the recent drop are: * A new analyst at Credit Suisse dug up the ol' SDN chestnut and suggested it would impact CSCO's margins in a 12-month timeframe (ridiculous assertion, but some people bought it). * Chambers, who clearly stated he couldn't comment on CSCO's quarter, said that other companies were experiencing mixed regional growth. * MKM downgrade (and upgrade of JNPR -- go figure)

Message.Msg: Aspiring model dies tragically: possible victim of road-rage fury Michael Williams, who also died, allegedly drove his car head-on into Chelsea Garrish’s SUV, killing her — but her two other passengers miraculously survive. Aspiring model Chelsea Gerrish was employed by U-Haul and the Tilted Kilt pub. An aspiring model from Georgia was killed when another driver slammed head-on into her SUV Friday morning. Chelsea Gerrish, 20, who was born in Somers Point, N.J., was the victim of 48-year-old Michael Williams' suspected road rage. Both died at the scene, reported the Gainesville Times. Aspiring model Gerrish was killed in a suspected road rage incident "He just hit somebody head-on. Oh no, oh no, oh no," another driver told 911. She called the dispatcher before the fatal crash to report that Williams had been trailing her and ramming her Highlander with his red Chevrolet pickup truck. "We have got a red truck following us," she said earlier. "He's been following us and he keeps turning off his lights on and off. He just hit us! He just hit us!"
